articles.headline: Google’s Antitrust Woes in Europe Are Likely to Grow
articles.snippet: Complainants contend the company favored its own mobile services over those of rivals in violation of European law.
articles.abstract: Complainants contend the company favored its own mobile services over those of rivals in violation of European law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google’s antitrust problems in Europe are about to get a whole lot bigger.

articles.headline: Intel to Cut 12,000 Jobs as PC Demand Plummets
articles.snippet: The company, the largest semiconductor maker, will lay off 11 percent of its work force as it shifts to supplying chips for phones and other devices.
articles.abstract: The company, the largest semiconductor maker, will lay off 11 percent of its work force as it shifts to supplying chips for phones and other devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors, said on Tuesday that it was laying off 12,000 people, about 11 percent of its work force, as it continues to reel from a long downturn in global demand for personal computers.

articles.headline: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Win Easily in New York Primary
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s win reclaimed control of the Republican race; Mrs. Clinton fought off another challenge from Bernie Sanders.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s win reclaimed control of the Republican race; Mrs. Clinton fought off another challenge from Bernie Sanders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump wrested back control of the Republican presidential race on Tuesday with a commanding victory in the New York primary, while Hillary Clinton dealt a severe blow to Senator Bernie Sanders with an unexpectedly strong win that led her to declare that the Democratic nomination was “in sight.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Saudi Threat to Sell U.S. Assets Could Hurt, but Mostly the Saudis
articles.snippet: A move by the kingdom to sell off holdings worth billions if Congress passes a bill allowing the Saudis to be sued over 9/11 would have little impact on America, experts say.
articles.abstract: A move by the kingdom to sell off holdings worth billions if Congress passes a bill allowing the Saudis to be sued over 9/11 would have little impact on America, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Saudi Arabia follows through on its recent threat to sell off its investments in the United States, the financial maneuver could be painful — mostly for Saudi Arabia.

articles.headline: A Homecoming, and a Triumph, for Hillary Clinton in New York
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton has had dramatic highs and crushing lows in her political career, but New York has always been the state that loved her back.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton has had dramatic highs and crushing lows in her political career, but New York has always been the state that loved her back.
articles.lead_paragraph: She danced the merengue in Washington Heights. She slammed down a mean game of dominoes in East Harlem.

articles.headline: E.U. Charges Dispute Google’s Claims That Android Is Open to All
articles.snippet: Europe’s competition chief said Google unfairly promoted its services with cellphone makers, limiting rivals in the smartphone software market.
articles.abstract: Europe’s competition chief said Google unfairly promoted its services with cellphone makers, limiting rivals in the smartphone software market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has long stressed that Android, its popular mobile software, is open for anyone to use, including its rivals.

articles.headline: Mitsubishi Admits Cheating on Fuel-Economy Tests
articles.snippet: The manipulation of testing procedures by the automaker’s engineers affected about 620,000 vehicles sold in Japan, the company’s president said.
articles.abstract: The manipulation of testing procedures by the automaker’s engineers affected about 620,000 vehicles sold in Japan, the company’s president said.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the latest scandal to hit the automobile industry, Mitsubishi Motors said on Wednesday that it had cheated on fuel-economy tests for an ultrasmall car it produces in Japan. The company acknowledged that its engineers had intentionally manipulated evaluations.

articles.headline: Choosing to Skip the Upgrade and Care for the Gadget You’ve Got
articles.snippet: As part of a movement against consumerism, more people are maintaining their electronics instead of constantly buying the newest, fastest model.
articles.abstract: As part of a movement against consumerism, more people are maintaining their electronics instead of constantly buying the newest, fastest model.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vincent Lai was working at a recycling facility in New York and sorting through a bin of used cellphones a few years ago when he dug up a Palm Treo, a smartphone that was discontinued last decade.

articles.headline: Harriet Tubman Ousts Andrew Jackson in Change for a $20
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said that women and civil rights leaders would also appear on the $5 and $10 notes.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said that women and civil rights leaders would also appear on the $5 and $10 notes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew on Wednesday announced the most sweeping and historically symbolic makeover of American currency in a century, proposing to replace the slaveholding Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill with Harriet Tubman, the former slave and abolitionist, and to add women and civil rights leaders to the $5 and $10 notes.

articles.headline: Flint Water Crisis Yields First Criminal Charges
articles.snippet: Two Michigan officials were accused of misleading other officials about the city’s water, and a city employee was charged with misconduct.
articles.abstract: Two Michigan officials were accused of misleading other officials about the city’s water, and a city employee was charged with misconduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Three government workers were charged with crimes on Wednesday for their roles in this city’s water crisis, accused in part of covering up evidence of lead contamination.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Richard Pérez-Peña
